summary: Use the periodic table as a model to predict element properties based on electron patterns.
Construct and revise explanations for how atomic substructures relate to periodic trends and chemical properties.
Plan and conduct investigations to gather evidence that mass is conserved in chemical reactions.
Develop models to illustrate how changes in particle interactions release or absorb energy in chemical processes.
Apply scientific principles to explain how reaction rates are affected by temperature, concentration, catalysts, and surface area.
Refine the design of a chemical system by specifying condition changes that increase product formation at equilibrium.
Use mathematical representations to support the claim that atoms and mass are conserved during chemical reactions.
Analyze data to support the claim that Newton’s second law describes the relationship among net force, mass, and acceleration.
Use mathematical representations to describe and predict the effects of forces between objects.
Apply scientific and engineering ideas to design, evaluate, and refine devices that minimize force on a macroscopic object.
Use mathematical representations of gravitation and electrostatic force to describe and predict interactions between objects.
Plan and conduct an investigation to provide evidence that charged objects exert forces on each other.
Create and revise a computational model to calculate energy change of one component in a system when energy flows in or out.
Develop and use models to illustrate how energy at the macroscopic scale relates to energy at the atomic scale.
Design, build, and refine a device that converts one form of energy into another within given constraints.
Plan and conduct an investigation to provide evidence that transferring thermal energy increases particle motion in matter.
Use mathematical representations to support claims about relationships among wave frequency, wavelength, and speed.
Evaluate questions about how wave interference, reflection, refraction, and absorption affect wave energy.
Apply principles of wave behavior to design devices that use wave interference patterns.
Evaluate the validity and reliability of claims that electromagnetic radiation can be described by a wave or photon model.
Communicate technical information about how modern communication devices use wave behavior and digital signals.
Construct explanations for how DNA structure determines the structure of proteins and specialized cell systems.
Develop and use models to illustrate hierarchical organization of interacting systems in multicellular organisms.
Plan and conduct investigations to provide evidence that feedback mechanisms maintain homeostasis.
Use models to illustrate how mitosis and differentiation produce and maintain complex organisms.
Use models to explain how photosynthesis converts light energy into stored chemical energy.
Construct and revise explanations for how matter and energy flow through cellular respiration.
Use models to illustrate that cellular respiration is a chemical process where bonds break and reform to release energy.
Use mathematical and computational models to support explanations of ecosystem carrying capacity and limiting factors.
Use mathematical representations to support and revise explanations of factors affecting ecosystem stability and biodiversity.
Construct and revise explanations for how matter cycles and energy flows through aerobic and anaerobic processes.
Use mathematical representations to support claims about how energy flows and matter cycles within an ecosystem.
Develop models to illustrate the role of photosynthesis and cellular respiration in carbon cycling among the biosphere.
Evaluate claims and evidence about the impacts of resource availability on organisms and populations.
Design, evaluate, and refine solutions that reduce human impacts on biodiversity and ecosystem services.
Evaluate evidence for how group behaviors increase survival and reproduction for individuals and species.
Ask questions to clarify how DNA and chromosomes provide instructions for traits transmitted through cell cycles.
Make and defend claims about how variation and distribution of traits in a population are influenced by genetic and environmental factors.
Communicate scientific information that common ancestry and biological evolution are supported by multiple lines of evidence.
Construct explanations based on evidence for factors leading to evolution and speciation.
Apply statistics and probability to support explanations that traits offer advantages that affect survival and reproduction.
Construct explanations for how natural selection leads to adaptation of populations.
Evaluate evidence that environmental changes influence species increase, emergence of new species, or extinction.
Create or revise simulations to test solutions that reduce human impacts on biodiversity.
Develop models of Earth-Sun-Moon orbits to explain seasons and solar energy variations.
Construct explanations of stellar properties and life cycles using evidence from light spectra and brightness.
Communicate scientific ideas about the expansion of the universe based on astronomical evidence.
Develop models to explain how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales.
Analyze geoscience data to explain feedbacks that stabilize or destabilize Earth’s systems.
Develop models to describe how circulating water at Earth’s surface and underground causes weathering and landform changes.
Use models to describe how energy from the sun and gravity drive cycling of water and weather patterns.
Plan and conduct investigations of the properties of water and its effects on Earth materials and surface processes.
Develop quantitative models to describe the cycling of carbon among Earth systems.
Construct explanations for how natural resources, hazards, and climate influence human activity.
Evaluate cost-benefit ratios of technologies that reduce human impacts on natural systems.
Create computational simulations to forecast and mitigate human impacts on Earth systems.
Evaluate or refine technological solutions that reduce impacts of human activities on natural systems.
Analyze geoscience data and climate models to make evidence-based forecasts of climate change.
Use computational models to illustrate how human activities modify Earth systems and to design solutions.
